test_series_info.title: JKSSB Junior Engineer (Electrical) - Complete Test Series
test_series_info.description: Comprehensive test series based on official JKSSB JEE Electrical syllabus

topics: Circuit laws: Ohm's law, KCL, KVL
Special machines: servo and stepper motors

sample_test.description: Sample test with 10 questions covering all 8 modules with relevant images
instructions: No negative marking for wrong answers
Some questions include diagrams/images for reference
Choose the most appropriate answer from given options

questions.question_text: In the circuit shown below, what is the equivalent resistance between points A and B?

image_reference.image_description: Circuit diagram showing resistors in series and parallel configuration

questions.explanation: Using series and parallel resistance formulas: For parallel resistors R_parallel = (R1 × R2)/(R1 + R2), and for series resistors R_series = R1 + R2. Analyzing the given circuit step by step, the equivalent resistance between points A and B works out to 15 Ω.
questions.learning_outcome: Apply network theorems to solve circuit problems

questions.question_text: According to Kirchhoff's Current Law (KCL), the algebraic sum of currents at any node in a circuit is:
questions.explanation: Kirchhoff's Current Law (KCL) states that the algebraic sum of all currents entering and leaving a node must equal zero. This is based on the fundamental principle of conservation of electric charge - charge cannot accumulate at a node.

questions.question_text: In the block diagram shown, what type of control system configuration is represented?

image_reference.image_description: Control system block diagram showing feedback configuration

options.B: Closed loop control system with negative feedback
options.C: Closed loop control system with positive feedback

questions.explanation: The diagram shows a closed loop control system with negative feedback, where the output is fed back and compared with the reference input to generate an error signal. This error signal drives the controller to minimize the difference between desired and actual output.

questions.question_text: The waveform displayed on the oscilloscope screen indicates which type of signal?

image_reference.image_description: Oscilloscope display showing various waveform patterns

questions.explanation: The oscilloscope display shows a smooth, continuous sinusoidal waveform with constant amplitude and frequency. This is characteristic of a pure sine wave without harmonic distortion, indicating a clean AC signal source.

questions.question_text: In a forward-biased PN junction diode, the width of the depletion region:
questions.explanation: In forward bias, the applied external voltage opposes the built-in potential barrier of the PN junction. This reduces the electric field across the junction, causing the depletion region width to decrease significantly, which allows majority carriers to cross the junction and conduct current.
questions.learning_outcome: Understand PN junction behavior under different bias conditions

questions.question_text: Looking at the logic gate symbols shown, which gate produces a HIGH output only when all inputs are HIGH?

image_reference.image_description: Various logic gate symbols with their corresponding truth tables

questions.explanation: The AND gate produces a HIGH (logic 1) output only when all of its inputs are HIGH (logic 1). If any input is LOW (logic 0), the output will be LOW (logic 0). This is the fundamental characteristic of the AND logic operation, implementing the Boolean multiplication function.
questions.learning_outcome: Identify logic gate symbols and their truth tables

questions.question_text: In the bridge rectifier circuit shown, what is the peak inverse voltage (PIV) across each diode?

image_reference.image_description: Full-wave bridge rectifier circuit diagram with four diodes

questions.explanation: In a bridge rectifier, during the negative half-cycle of the input, two diodes are reverse-biased. Each of these reverse-biased diodes experiences a peak inverse voltage equal to the peak input voltage Vm. This is different from center-tap rectifiers where PIV = 2Vm.

questions.question_text: In the transformer equivalent circuit shown, what does the magnetizing reactance Xm represent?

image_reference.image_description: Transformer equivalent circuit showing various parameters

options.C: Reactance due to mutual flux linkage

questions.explanation: The magnetizing reactance Xm in the transformer equivalent circuit represents the reactance due to the mutual flux that links both primary and secondary windings. It accounts for the magnetizing current component required to establish the mutual flux in the core.

questions.question_text: The synchronous reactance of a synchronous machine is the sum of:
questions.explanation: Synchronous reactance (Xs) is the sum of armature leakage reactance (Xl) and armature reaction reactance (Xa). It represents the total inductive reactance of the armature circuit under synchronous operating conditions and is used in the simplified equivalent circuit of synchronous machines.
questions.learning_outcome: Understand synchronous machine parameters and equivalent circuits

questions.question_text: In power system protection, which type of relay is most suitable for protecting long transmission lines?
questions.explanation: Distance relays (impedance relays) are most suitable for long transmission line protection because they measure the impedance to the fault location, providing both selectivity and speed of operation. They are less affected by varying system conditions compared to overcurrent relays and can provide zone-wise protection.
questions.learning_outcome: Select appropriate protection schemes for power system components

full_test_series_structure.note: This sample demonstrates the structure for 10 questions. The complete test series would contain 5 tests with 120 questions each (600 total questions) following the same format.

test_1.name: Test 1 - Comprehensive Coverage
test_1.focus: Balanced coverage of all modules with fundamental concepts

test_4.name: Test 4 - Mixed Difficulty
test_4.focus: Combination of easy, medium, and difficult questions
